titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Collection in the Library of Congress
titlestmt.author: Prepared by Erin K. Davis with the assistance of David Kennaly and Jay Kempen under the direction of Meredith Shedd-Driskel

publicationstmt.publisher: Rare Book and Special Collections Division, Library of Congress

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Elizabeth Gettins, Library of Congress, Rare Book and Special Collections Division, 2013

did.head: Collection Summary

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Library of Congress. Rare Book and Special Collections Division

physdesc.label: Extent
physdesc.extent: Linear feet of shelf space occupied: 30 feet

did.langmaterial: Collection material is primarily in English.

repository.label: Location
repository.corpname: Rare Book and Special Collections Division Library of Congress

did.abstract: The collection is divided into five categories: Correspondence and Typescripts, Grenfell Press Publications, Miscellaneous Publications, and Oversize materials.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

controlaccess.head: Organizations
controlaccess.corpname: Grenfell Press Archive (Library of Congress) DLC

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Grenfell Press Archive was purchased by the Library of Congress in 1993. This original purchase includes correspondence and production materials associated with the operation of the Grenfell Press from its beginning in 1979 through 1992. Also included are several published items that were lacking from the Rare Book Collection's almost complete holdings of Grenfell Press titles; these items have been cataloged separately and housed with the Grenfell Press Collection. The Grenfell Press Archive has been arranged chronologically in order that, as works continue to be published, additional installments may be acquired and the archive expanded.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The archive was arranged and inventoried in the last quarter of 1994 by Erin Davis and David Kennaly under the direction of Meredith Shedd-Driskel.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright in the unpublished writings within the Grenfell Press Archive in the custody of the Library of Congress is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The records of the Grenfell Press materials are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Rare Book and Special Collections Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container number, Grenfell Press Archive, Rare Book and Special Collections Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Leslie Miller began her press in 1979 with the broadside Typefaces and the next year produced her first book with the same title. Over the next decade she has since collaborated with the authors Joyce Carol Oates, Guy Davenport, James Laughlin, Ann Lauterbach, John Hawkes, Gilbert Sorrentino, William S. Burroughs, William Gass, Harry Mathews, Bradford Morrow, and the artists Trevor Winkfield, Francesco Clemente, James Nares, Ellen Phelan, Joel Shapiro, and others. Initially the press produced fine press books, but in recent years it has moved successfully into the livre d'artiste category.

No aspect of bookmaking escapes Miller's intense interest, which is most unusual in a world where printmakers often care little about typography, typographers look upon binding as a distracting afterthought, and binders view all of it merely as a medium for their own form of expression. These fractured attitudes result in books that are interesting in particulars but defective as wholes. Miller has managed to transcend the limitations any one of these crafts might have imposed upon her vision, creating books that are thoroughly imaginative. The ideal of the press is to create a book that is a balanced and unified statement in which all of its integral parts illuminate one another.
- Larry Sullivan, Chief Rare Book and Special Collections Division

The Grenfell Press Archive, which chronicles the book production, publicity, and business transactions associated with the Grenfell Press, has been arranged broadly into three categories: correspondence and typescripts, material relating to the production of individual works published by the Grenfell Press, and material relating to miscellaneous publications designed (but not published) by the press. The section comprising correspondence and typescripts relates to general business matters of the press; correspondence relating specifically to the production of an individual work is grouped with the production materials for that work. These production materials have been arranged in chronological order by publication date of the item to which they relate and subarranged by type; for example, correspondence, followed by typescripts and paste-ups, material relating to illustration and binding, etc. The original 1993 purchase also includes several published items that were lacking from the Rare Book Collection's almost complete holdings of Grenfell Press titles; these items have been cataloged separately (a source note has been added to the cataloging record to identify them) and housed with the Grenfell Press Collection. Also, in order to connect the material in the archive generally to the resulting publications housed in the Grenfell Press Collection, the record number for each publication is noted in parentheses in this finding aid. An index of names (authors and artists) and titles of publications has also been provided, but it should be noted that the section comprising correspondence and typescripts has not been indexed.
Correspondence and Typescripts (1981-1989) General business correspondence (1980-1994), miscellaneous typescripts and material relating to small projects (e.g., stationery, bookplates, etc.)

The Grenfell Press Publications (1980-1994) Correspondence associated with the production of a particular publication; production materials, including typescripts, proofs, paste-ups, binder's dummies, etc.; prospectuses and material relating to publicity.

The Miscellaneous Publications (1981-1991) Publications designed by the Grenfell Press, including work for New Directions, Callaway Editions, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, Targ Editions, Conjunctions Magazine, etc.

Pamphlets (series contains Pamphlets, short monographs, off prints, and photocopies, primarily of published materials, in English and west European languages. Many published by anarchist organizations, many with inscriptions. Arranged alphabetically by author/title.
The Oversize (1983-1992) Oversize material organized and described according to the series, folders, and boxes from which the items were removed.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Records
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in 4 series:
